ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Research experience. It all depends on your project.
I did a CS senior project. I felt like it was mainly an arbitrary project that doesn't make a difference on the world.

This is entirely dependent upon which senior project one decides to complete -- in my case, I learned all about modeling dark matter haloes and the factors impacting their splashback radii! I also, more practically, gained a lot of experience with Python and SatGen specifically throughout the project. That said, it's entirely up to the one completing the project which knowledge, skills, and insights they would like to develop!
I learned a lot about my thesis topic - a very self-driven process.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Its a good experience if you find an interesting project and a good mentor.
There is literally no guidance given to us. I probably talked with my advisor three times the whole semester and got no input from the DUS.

This is a senior project, so this will depend entirely on your advisor -- in my case, Prof. Nagai and my mentors did an excellent job keeping me on track with my project while allowing me sufficient independence to make mistakes and learn along the way!

I think it's 100% dependent on you and your thesis advisor to dictate how it goes. For me, a challenge was not having much guidance or meeting very often with my advisor; however, I fully recognize that that is both my and my advisor's responsibility and shortcoming.

strengths - up to the student what they want to do research in
weakness - if you're advisor is constantly busy, that can screw your plans up

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You have to take it for AMTH degree
Nope but we have to do it.
Yes -- if you are an applied math major and intend to graduate, that is!
If you're an AMTH major, you don't have a choice.
if you're applied math, then you have no other choice
